Academia doesn't exist in a vacuum. It isn't a pristine realm standing apart from the rest of the world. If anything, it is as gritty and grubby if not more so.

If "money is power" in our world, and academic politicians (college presidents and chancellors) are consummate careerists (if only because "academic politics is so vicious because the rewards are so terribly small", quoting Prof. Kissinger among others -- many others), it stands to reason that the last thing any academic politician worthy of his cap and gown will do -- being just one among "too many people battling over tiny ant hills" (academic politics as defined by Lester Thurow) -- is forgo access to any campus money-source however meager or polluted; especially funny-money that can be used to tilt the balance of power in his or her favor.

The practical exercise of power on campus can be boiled down to a phrase: "money becomes available." "The Chancellor give'th, and take'th away". Since "no idea is too good or pure that an academic committee cannot kill it" (Kissinger again), the reactionary self-interest of a myopic parochial professoriate can only be overcome by flattery, threats, deceit, log rolling, rumor-mongering, sleight-of-hand, backstabbing, committee-wielded cudgels and, of course, bribery. Not so very different from what goes on inside the hallowed halls of Congress behind the facade of smiles, plastic gravitas and forced conviviality when you think about it. Or the Pentagon.

Right on Mr. Miner. We're already past the safe limit for greenhouse gases. So what you say here also applies to natural gas. Burning the stuff produces 40% as much CO2 as burning coal and/or oil, and upstream leaks add copious amounts of methane into the mix — methane being 72% more potent a greenhouse gas in the short term and 25% more in the long term than CO2.

The choice is simple, really. The fossil fuel era comes to an end or we do.

The Other Argument Against Oil Drilling in Arctic Seas

We are already 50 ppm past the safe limit for CO2 alone, and that doesn't count the 55 ppm equivalent from other greenhouse gasses. The safe limit is 350 ppm CO2 plus equivalent. We are now at 400ppm CO2 alone. We should have banned fossil fuel fired power plants over 500 megawatts capacity in or before 1980.

We need the supply of fossil fuels to run out to protect our food supply from GW alias CC. On 25 May, I drove across Illinois and back. I was amazed at how many fields have not been plowed yet. Some fields have row crops sprouting, but the corn should be knee high by now. Last year it was drought. This year it is too much rain and repeated floods. The fields are too muddy to drive a tractor on. Both droughts and floods are made worse by GW.

Such fraudulent links pointing to counterfeit merchandise can be found elsewhere too, so I think it's fair to lift some of that responsibility off of Facebook.

That isn't entirely true. The commitment to keep slavery from expanding was partly based on the belief that if slavery couldn't expand, it would be put on a course towards ultimate extinction. The South believed it as well, that's why the issue of being able to expand slavery to the territories was one worth fighting an election over and seceding when they lost.

The article is a little simplistic. The British population initially was much more supportive of the north as can be seen by the much larger number of volunteers that went to the North. There were strong economic reasons for supporting the south based on the cotton trade. Add to this, situations like the Trent affair, forcing British citizens into the union army and the incompetence of union military leadership early in the war and the real question becomes if the British were so pro south why didn't they intervene since maintaining the union had no value to Britain. Early in the US civil war France advocated recognizing and supporting the south, so Britain would have had a major ally.  In addition US behavior and aggression provided more reasons to support the south. The US had threatened an invasion of Canada multiple times since its failure in the War of 1812 and Britain had to spend massive amounts of money to fortify and defend the colony. Seward head of the state department under Lincoln had advocated invading and annexing Canada in his presidential run and at one point had advocated starting a war with Britain to distract the south from succession. The north made no commitment to end slavery and won't have if it meant the union could be cobbled back together. Certainly the US was not considered a major power such as Russia in the recently fought Crimean war. Its navy ranked fifth or sixth.  Despite all this the British did not recognize the south.

Not at all. Virginia was on the fence but its "Unionism", except for the Northwest counties that later became West Virginia, was highly conditional. That condition was that the US government take no action to compel the end of the rebellion. The action that pushed Virginia off its perch was President Lincoln's call for troops after the Confederates fired on Ft. Sumter and the fort surrendered.

The Morrill Tariff was passed by the 36th Congress (1859-1861), not nearly as Republican as the 37th Congress, and signed into law by President Buchanan shortly before his term in office ended. It's totally unlikely it would have passed without the resignation of congressmen and senators whose states had joined the rebellion. Its passage has to be placed in the context of the tariff law immediately before it, the Tariff of 1857, which reduced tariffs to levels not seen since 1816. Popular in the South, the Tariff of 1857 was blamed, rightly or wrongly, for the Panic of 1857 and resulting depression in the North.

The date that needs to be focused on is November 6, 1860, the date on which the Presidential Election of 1869 was held. As they had in 1856, slave states threatened to secede if the Republican candidate for President won. The slave states saw the Republican Party as the party of abolition. In 1860, the voters outside the slave states refused to be intimidated by the threat. Lincoln won and the rebellion began.
